title: Caroline Mallmann

content: Brazilian forestry engineer and botanist interested in taxonomy and systematics (with a focus on Neotropical Sapotaceae), Amazonian tree flora, spectroscopy as a tool for tree species identification, species distribution modeling, floristic studies, and forest ecology.
summary: Brazilian forestry engineer and botanist interested in taxonomy and systematics (with a focus on Neotropical Sapotaceae), Amazonian tree flora, spectroscopy as a tool for tree species identification, species distribution modeling, floristic studies, and forest ecology.
title: Caroline Vasconcelos

title: Flávia Durgante

content: Hilana Louise Hadlich graduated in Forest Engineering from UFPR in 2015 and completed her master’s degree in Tropical Forest Sciences at INPA in 2017, where she began her studies in near-infrared spectroscopy, developing this technology for application in Forest Inventories to ensure greater accuracy in species identification. In 2021, she entered the doctoral program and deepened her research with field spectroscopy, testing the technology in different ecosystems in the Amazon.
summary: Hilana Louise Hadlich graduated in Forest Engineering from UFPR in 2015 and completed her master’s degree in Tropical Forest Sciences at INPA in 2017, where she began her studies in near-infrared spectroscopy, developing this technology for application in Forest Inventories to ensure greater accuracy in species identification. In 2021, she entered the doctoral program and deepened her research with field spectroscopy, testing the technology in different ecosystems in the Amazon.
title: Hilana Hadlich

content: Northern Brazilian, biologist, and biology teacher. She has experience in teaching, applied botany, taxonomy, and plant ecology, with a focus on the Amazon, conservation, and development of the state of Amazonas. She is currently conducting research in spectroscopy, aiming to improve and standardize spectroscopy techniques within botanical science.
